properties.name: Barnard Mountain
properties.notes:
Barnard Mountain https://www.nps.gov/places/barnard-mountain.htm A 2 mile out and back trail leads to the top of 1,558ft (474 m) Barnard Mountain. Barnard Mountain offers an exceptional view of Mount Katahdin, Katahdin Lake, and the valley below. The hike begins on an old logging road (also known as a tote road) and passes through deciduous forest at the lower elevations. As you gain elevation, you will pass through stunning boreal forest and glacial erratics.

Biking is not permitted on the trail up to Barnard Mountain.
 

Elevation Gain: 792ft / 241m

Distance (Round-Trip): 4 miles

Difficulty: Easy to Moderate

Restrooms: There are no restrooms available at the trailhead. The closest vault toilet is at the Katahdin Overlook also on the Loop Road. There is another vault toilet at Deasey Ponds Parking Area.

Water: Potable water is not available at this location.

Parking: The most direct access point to Barnard Mountain is at the trailhead located near mile 12 of the Katahdin Loop Road (45.91561,-68.76049).

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.

properties.name: Barnard Mountain Trailhead
properties.notes:
Barnard Mountain Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/barnard-mountain-trailhead.htm The Barnard Mountain trailhead is located just before mile marker 12 on the Katahdin Loop Road. The hike to the top of Barnard Mountain is 4 miles round trip. From the top there is a spectacular view of neighboring Baxter State Park and Mount Katahdin. 

The International Appalachian Trail (IAT) also starts from this trailhead. The IAT extends on from the Appalachian Trail. The trail follows the ancient Appalachian Mountains, now separated by the North Atlantic Ocean. The IAT links traces of these mountains around the arc of the North Atlantic. The section of the trail that runs through Maine starts here and continues through the national monument for 30 miles, then continues another 100 miles to Fort Fairfield, Maine, and then on into Canada, Greenland, and Europe, ending in Morocco.

properties.name: Bowlin Falls
properties.notes:
Bowlin Falls
https://www.nps.gov/places/bowlin-falls.htm

While paddling down the East Branch of the Penobscot River, Bowlin Falls is the last waterfall and portage within national monument boundaries, There are no trails to Bowlin Falls and it is only accessible by water.

properties.name: Deasey Mountain
properties.notes:
Deasey Mountain https://www.nps.gov/places/deasey-mountain.htm At 1,942 feet, Deasey Mountain is the tallest peak in Katahdin Woods and Waters. The summit offers 360-degree views of the surrounding landscape. Access to Deasey Mountain is by way of the International Appalachian Trail, with the shortest hiking distance being five miles from Wassataquoik Gate. A ford across Wassataquoik Stream is necessary.

Sitting atop the mountain is the historic Deasey Mountain fire lookout. The lookout was constructed by the Maine Forest Service in 1929 and used for fire detection until 1969. It is one of the very few ground houses in Maine. Camping is not permitted at the peak or at the fire lookout. Please reserve a campsite or continue to hike to a designated site within the monument.
 

Elevation Gain: 1,593ft / 485m

Distance (Round-Trip): 10 miles

Difficulty: Difficult

Restrooms: A vault toilet is located in the parking area at the Wassataquoik Gate trailhead.

Parking: Parking is available at Wassataquoik gate trailhead on Orin Falls Road.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.

Use caution when fording Wassataquoik Stream. Review stream crossing safety before your trip. There is no potable water within the monument. Plan accordingly!

properties.name: Deasey Mountain Fire Lookout
properties.notes:
Deasey Mountain Fire Lookout
https://www.nps.gov/places/deasey-mountain-fire-lookout.htm

One of the very few groundhouse lookouts in Maine, Deasey Mountain Lookout was constructed by the Maine Forest Service in 1929 and used for detection until 1969.

properties.name: Deasey Ponds
properties.notes:
Deasey Ponds https://www.nps.gov/places/deasey-ponds.htm Deasey Pond is one of the shorter hikes available within Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument at 0.6 miles one-way. This hike offers a charming view of a pond within the northern boreal forests of Maine. With glacial erratics breaking the water’s surface you can see clues of the landscape’s glacial past. The pond’s trailhead is located just before mile 1 on the Katahdin Loop Road.
 

Elevation Gain: 72ft / 21m

Distance(Round-Trip): 1.2 miles

Difficulty: Easy

Restrooms: There is a vault toilet at the parking area.

Parking: Parking is available just west of the trailhead. The parking area is located to the right on the Loop Road at approximately 45.87072,-68.68235

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.

properties.name: Deasey Ponds Trail Parking Lot
properties.notes:
Deasey Ponds Trail Parking Lot https://www.nps.gov/places/deasey-ponds-trail-parking-area.htm Park your vehicle here to begin your scenic hike to Deasey Ponds and/or carefully cross the road south of the parking lot and follow an esker south to a beautiful viewpoint. This is a one way traffic parking lot and fits approximately 10 vehicles. Please follow the enter and exit signs accordingly. There is a vault toilet located to the left by the entrace. There is no potable water. 

Accessibility:
The surface of the parking area is made of dirt, gravel, and rocks. It is leveled, but the surface can be uneven and muddy depending on the season. The vault toilet meets ADA standards.

Hours:
Open 24/7 when the Katahdin Loop Road is opened to traffic.

Getting Here:
Take Swift Brook Road to reach the parking area at approximately 45.87072,-68.68235

properties.name: Esker Wetland
properties.notes:
Esker Wetland https://www.nps.gov/places/esker-wetland.htm Esker Wetland offers a viewpoint of a wetland ecosystem formed by Sandbank Stream. This calm wetland area is bordered by deciduous forest.

Start at the Deasey Ponds Trail parking lot to access Esker Wetland. Follow a trail atop an esker and down to the wetland viewpoint. Use caution to cross the road south of the parking lot to find the trailhead that leads to the viewpoint. Depending on conditions, this area may experience flooding and high water levels.


Elevation Gain: 50ft / 15m

Distance (Round-Trip): 1 mile

Difficulty: Easy

Restrooms: A vault toilet is located at at Deasey Ponds Trailhead parking lot.

Parking: Park at the Deasey Ponds parking lot.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.

properties.name: Grand Pitch
properties.notes:
Grand Pitch https://www.nps.gov/places/grand-pitch.htm Grand Pitch spans approximately 200 feet across the East Branch of the Penobscot River and drops approximately 20 feet. The river at Grand Pitch cuts through some of the oldest rocks in the local area. The Grand Pitch Formation is predominately slate (metamorphic rock), siltsone (sedimentary rock), and fine-grained quartzite (metamorphic rock). The rocks of the Grand Pitch formation are believed to date to the early Cambrian period, over approximately 500 million years ago. Hike or bike along the IAT to experience this geological feature. Paddlers must portage around Grand Pitch.
 

Elevation Gain: 166ft / 50m

Distance (Round-Trip): 7 miles

Difficulty: Moderate

Restrooms: Vault toilets are available at the North Gate parking lot and Oxbow Picnic Area.

Parking: Parking is available at the Haskell Gate trailhead parking area.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.

properties.name: Haskell Gate
properties.notes:
Haskell Gate https://www.nps.gov/places/haskell-gate.htm

Haskell Gate is where visitors can access points of interest or hike-in campsites in the northern section of the monument. All trails past Haskell Gate are for hiking or biking only. Just south of the gate on New River Road is a designated parking area for vehicles. Please do not park in front of the gate or block the gate.

Note: During the winter, New River Road is closed at the North Gate. Vehicles must park at the North Gate parking area. Visitors can access Haskell Gate by foot. Ski trails are often groomed to Haskell Gate from January through March.

properties.name: Haskell Rock Pitch
properties.notes:
Haskell Rock Pitch https://www.nps.gov/places/haskell-rock-pitch.htm Haskell Rock Pitch refers to the series of rapids in the East Branch of the Penobscot River.  A large 20-foot high conglomerate rock (a coarse-grained sedimentary rock composed of fragments larger than 2 millimeters in diameter), Haskell Rock protrudes out from the rapids. The conglomerate rock feature is named after a logger, William Haskell, who died here.

Paddlers are advised to take portage trails around all rapids within the monument. For those traveling by foot or bicycle, start at Haskell Gate and follow the trail east for approximately 2 miles. A primitive campsite is located at nearby at Haskell Deadwater.
 

Elevation Gain: 103ft / 31m

Distance (Round-Trip): 4 Miles

Difficulty: Easy

Restrooms: The closest vault toilets are located at the North Gate parking lot and at Oxbow Picnic Area.

Parking: Parking is available at the Haskell Gate.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.

properties.name: Katahdin Overlook
properties.notes:
Katahdin Overlook
https://www.nps.gov/places/katahdin-overlook.htm

Travelers on the Katahdin Loop Road can pause here to enjoy unparalleled views of Katahdin, Millinocket Lake, and other prominent landmarks stretching out to the west. Access is via a short driveway at Mile 6.4 leading uphill to a clearing and parking area. A vault toilet and several picnic tables make this a popular rest stop. After sunset, this location also serves as an excellent night-sky viewing area for stargazers. Camping is located nearby at the Sandbank Stream campsites.

properties.name: Katahdin Viewpoint
properties.notes:
Katahdin Viewpoint
https://www.nps.gov/places/katahdin-viewpoint.htm

Katahdin Viewpoint is a remote location in the Seboeis Parcel to enjoy a glimpse of Mount Katahdin from a the distance. It is also a good location to stargaze at night. There are no facilities at this location.

properties.name: Kimball Deadwater
properties.notes:
Kimball Deadwater https://www.nps.gov/places/kimball-deadwater.htm Kimball Deadwater is a wetland area located next to the American Thread Road. It is an important habitat for a variety of wildlife, making it a great viewing area for wildlife. You may see waterfowl, amphibians, beavers, or even moose while visiting Kimball Deadwater.

Elevation Gain: None

Distance (Round-Trip): 0.2 miles

Restrooms: There are no restrooms available in this section of the monument.

Parking: Parking is available at the trailhead located on the American Thread Road.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.

properties.name: Little Messer Pond
properties.notes:
Little Messer Pond https://www.nps.gov/places/little-messer-pond.htm Little Messer Pond is one of the few tranquil ponds deep within Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument. The pond features unique plant life including peat moss and pitcher plants. It also offers great views of the Traveler Mountain. The shortest route to Little Messer Pond is along the International Appalachian Trail beginning at Haskell Gate.
 

Elevation Gain: 116ft / 35m

Distance (Round-Trip): 6 miles

Difficulty: Easy to moderate

Restrooms: Vault toilets are available at the North Gate and Oxbow Picnic Area. Follow best practices for remote waste management if needed.

Parking: Parking is available at the Haskell Gate parking area.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.

properties.name: Lunksoos Boat Launch
properties.notes:
Lunksoos Boat Launch https://www.nps.gov/places/lunksoos-launch.htm At the heart of Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument lies the East Branch of the Penobscot River, which runs the length of the monument north to south. From native Penobscots to noted American visitors like Henry David Thoreau, this waterway has been an important corridor of travel for centuries.

Lunksoos Boat Launch is a small gravel boat launch near the historic site of Lunksoos Camps. It offers a put-in point for paddlers wishing to head upstream to the river's confluence with the Seboeis, or downstream to Whetstone Falls and the main stem of the Penobscot beyond.

The parking lot and vault toilet is located across the Seboeis Road. Unload your belongings by the boat ramp and park in the designated parking lot.

properties.name: Lunksoos Mountain
properties.notes:
Lunksoos Mountain https://www.nps.gov/places/lunksoos-mountain.htm Lunksoos Mountain at 1,762 ft / 537 m, is within the heart of Katahdin Woods & Waters National Monument. From the peak you will see magnificent views of forests, rivers, and mountains all around, including Mount Katahdin. Reach the top of Lunksoos Mountain by hiking 6.3 miles one-way along the International Appalachian Trail from Wassataquoik Gate trailhead. A stream crossing is necessary by Wassataquoik Ford to reach the summit.
 

Elevation Gain: 1,332ft / 405m

Distance (Round-Trip): 12.6 miles

Difficulty: Difficult

Restrooms: A vault toilet is located in the parking area at the Wassataquoik Gate trailhead.

Parking: Parking is available at Wassataquoik Gate.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.

Use caution when fording Wassataquoik Stream. Review stream crossing safety before your trip.

properties.name: Lynx Pond
properties.notes:
Lynx Pond https://www.nps.gov/places/lynx_pond.htm Lynx Pond is accessed via a short out and back, ADA accessible trail. The viewing platform at Lynx Pond offers those driving along the Katahdin Loop Road a chance to get out of their vehicle and observe a rich natural community within the monument. Standing in the open air you may hear the rapping of a woodpecker’s beak against bark, the splashing of a duck’s wing against water, or see a solitary moose diving below the surface to snack on aquatic vegetation. Look for signs to Lynx Pond at mile 2.2 of the Katahdin Loop Road.

Elevation Gain: None

Distance (Round-Trip): 0.2 miles

Difficulty: Easy

Restrooms: There are no restrooms available at the trailhead. The closest vault toilet is at Deasey Ponds Parking Area.

Water: Potable water is not available at this location.

Parking: There is ADA parking next to the trailhead. More parking is available just past the trailhead on the Katahdin Loop Road. Once parked, follow the short gravel trail from the parking area that will lead you back to the Lynx Pond Trailhead.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.

properties.name: Messer Pond
properties.notes:
Messer Pond https://www.nps.gov/places/messer-pond.htm Messer Pond is one of five state heritage ponds in Katahdin Woods & Waters National Monument. It is also one of four Great Ponds within the monument. The state of Maine gives heritage fish waters special protection because wild brook trout are self-sustaining and not maintained by stocking. Messer Pond was last stocked in 1961. Invasive fish pose a major threat to these wild brook trout.

Messer Pond is located in a remote area of the monument and requires a 9 mile out and back hike.
 

Elevation: 179ft / 54m

Distance: 9 miles

Difficulty: Moderate

Restrooms: The nearest vault toilets are located at the North Gate parking lot and Oxbow Picnic Area.

Parking: Parking is available at the Haskell Gate parking lot.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.

properties.name: Mile 0 Katahdin Loop Road Entrance
properties.notes:
Mile 0 Katahdin Loop Road Entrance
https://www.nps.gov/places/mile0.htm

Welcome to the Katahdin Loop Road, a 17-mile scenic drive through Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument. Scenic views and wildlife viewing opportunities abound past the gate at Mile 0, and various trails for hiking, bicycling, or horseback riding can be accessed along this route. A small pullout before the entrance to the offers parking for a single vehicle and access to a nearby marsh via a short trail up and over a prominent glacial esker.

properties.name: Mile 1 Katahdin Loop Road-First View
properties.notes: Mile 1 Katahdin Loop Road-First View https://www.nps.gov/places/first_view.htm Just past mile marker 1 on the Katahdin Loop Road, a small pullout on the left provides a first view of almost mile-high Mount Katahdin at 5,267 feet above sea level in neighboring Baxter State Park. Katahdin, which translates to “greatest mountain” in Penobscot, is adjacent to the monument and the prominent visual feature in the region. Katahdin is held sacred by the Maliseet, Micmac, Passamaquoddy, and Penobscot nations and the geology within and around the monument is central to oral histories, traditions, and cultural practices for each tribal community.

properties.name: Mile 3.2 Katahdin Loop Road-Black Spruce Bog
properties.notes:
Mile 3.2 Katahdin Loop Road-Black Spruce Bog
https://www.nps.gov/places/mile-3-2-katahdin-loop-road-black-spruce-bog.htm

Along the roadside a black spruce bog contains rhodora (wild azalea) and swamp maple as well as a variety of other ferns and bog plants. Listen and watch for alder flycatcher, magnolia, palm and Canada warblers, swamp and white-throated sparrows, and hermit thrush.

properties.name: Mile 7.7 Katahdin Loop Road Viewpoint
properties.notes:
Mile 7.7 Katahdin Loop Road Viewpoint
https://www.nps.gov/places/katahdin-loop-road-viewpoint-mile-7-7.htm

Mile 7.7 on the Katahdin Loop Road offers a great view of Katahdin as well as the surrounding forests.

properties.name: Mile 8 Katahdin Loop Road Viewpoint
properties.notes:
Mile 8 Katahdin Loop Road Viewpoint
https://www.nps.gov/places/katahdin-loop-road-viewpoint-mile-8.htm

The mile 8 viewpoint on Katahdin Loop Road provides a view of Katahdin framed by forest. The view is especially dramatic during peak fall foliage, which typically occurs in mid to late September.

properties.name: Mile 8.2 Katahdin Loop Road Viewpoint
properties.notes: Mile 8.2 Katahdin Loop Road Viewpoint https://www.nps.gov/places/katahdin-loop-road-viewpoint-mile-8-2.htm At mile 8.2 on the Katahdin Loop Road you can see the glacially carved landscape surrounding Mount Katahdin.

properties.name: Monument Line
properties.notes:
Monument Line https://www.nps.gov/places/monument-line.htm The Monument Line practically cuts Katahdin Woods & Waters National Monument in half. Don't let the name fool you, this survey line is much older than the national monument. 

At the end of the Revolutionary War, the Treaty of Paris failed to specify a clear boundary between Maine and New Brunswick. In 1796, negotiators ran a "monument line" due north from the St. Croix River's headwaters to what was described in the treaty as the "highlands" separating rivers draining into the St. Lawrence from those entering the Atlantic - the agreed-upon northern boundary.

Upon Maine's 1820 separation from Massachusetts, Joseph Norris was hired to lay out the boundaries of these unallocated lands between the two states by blazing the trees with markers. In 1825 Maine formed the Maine Boundary Commission authorizing a survey to establish an east to west line for laying out townships: The Monument Line.

This survey allowed an equitable distribution of lands not already incorporated or otherwise conveyed by Massachusetts. Starting from a point where the boundary between Maine and New Brunswick ceases to be the St. Croix River and heads due north (the 1796 boundary), Joseph C. Norris, Sr., and his son ran the line to the west in the summer of 1825. By September, they had reached the Seboeis River, at which point they had to leave the woods for other survey work. Returning in November Norris built a raft to cross the Seboeis, and continued the line west in the face of approaching winter, crossing the East Branch, the Wassataquoik, and on to Katahdin, where on November 10th, in "intensely cold" weather, he reached an enormous drop-off into Northwest Basin, which forced him to abandon the survey for the year. This line allowed for the formation of townships bringing in people like William Hunt, of the notable Hunt Farm, into the area for logging.

Tensions were already running high as lumber operators from Maine and New Brunswick competed for timber in northern Maine. This would eventually lead to the Aroostook War in 1838.

properties.name: Mount Katahdin - Baxter State Park
properties.notes:
Mount Katahdin - Baxter State Park https://www.nps.gov/places/katahdin-baxter-state-park.htm Katahdin, which translates to "Greatest Mountain" in Penobscot, is the highest mountain in the state of Maine at 5,269 feet.

Katahdin is adjacent to Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument and the prominent visual feature in the region. Katahdin is held sacred by the Maliseet, Micmac, Passamaquoddy, and Penobscot nations and the geology within and around the monument is central to oral histories, traditions, and cultural practices for each tribal community.

Baxter Peak on Mount Katahdin is the northern terminus of the Appalachian National Scenic Trail. For more information about climbing Katahdin visit Baxter State Park's website.

properties.name: North Gate
properties.notes:
North Gate https://www.nps.gov/places/north-gate.htm The North Gate is the northern access point to the monument. It offers a parking area, vault toilet, and an information kiosk.

During the winter, the parking lot by the North Gate is the only maintained parking area in the monument. Park here and access the trailhead for groomed cross-country ski trails and snowshoeing routes during the winter season. Grooming for cross country ski trails will occur when snow accumulation is adequate.

properties.name: Orin Falls
properties.notes:
Orin Falls https://www.nps.gov/places/orin-falls.htm Large boulders in Wassataquoik Stream cause its waters to churn and tumble through the rapids of Orin Falls. The geology in this area hint at a glacial past. This location provides for a scenic picnic and fishing spot. Orin Falls is accessed via a 3 mile out and back hike or bike, mostly along an old streamside logging road. Prepare for high concentrations of biting and stinging insects during the spring and summer months.
 

Elevation Gain: 87ft / 26m

Distance (Round-Trip): 6 Miles

Difficulty: Easy

Restrooms: There is a vault toilet located at Wassataquoik Gate parking area

Water: Potable water is not available anywhere inside of Katahdin Woods and Waters. Prepare accordingly.

Parking: Parking is available at Wassataquoik Gate.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife

properties.name: Oxbow Picnic Area
properties.notes:
Oxbow Picnic Area https://www.nps.gov/places/oxbow.htm Oxbow Picnic Area is located at the top of a steep embankment along the East Branch of the Penobscot River. Enjoy a picnic with a view of the waterway as it enters a series of sharp bends known as the Oxbow. 

To get to the Oxbow Picnic Site, follow New River Road south past the North Gate parking area and turn onto Oxbow Road. Follow Oxbow road until you reach the picnic site. There is a vault toilet and a couple picnic tables at this location.

properties.name: Park Sign - American Thread Road
properties.notes:
Park Sign - American Thread Road
https://www.nps.gov/places/park-sign-american-thread-road.htm

The Katahdin Woods & Waters National Monument park sign for welcoming visitors into the Seboeis Parcel of the national monument.

properties.name: Park Sign - Swift Brook Road
properties.notes:
Park Sign - Swift Brook Road
https://www.nps.gov/places/park-sign-swift-brook-road.htm

Katahdin Woods & Waters National Monument park sign that welcomes visitors to the Hunt Farm parcel of the national monument as they continue to either the Katahdin Loop Road or Lunksoos Camps.

properties.name: Pond Pitch
properties.notes:
Pond Pitch https://www.nps.gov/places/pond-pitch.htm Pond Pitch is located in the East Branch of the Penobscot River. It gained its name from the pool just above the ledge of the waterfall. It is part of a series of pitches, or rapids, known as Grand Falls. Hike or bike 3 miles out and back to the viewpoint of Pond Pitch. Paddlers are advised to portage around all falls and pitches. Please be mindful of the campsite nearby.
 

Elevation Gain: 140ft / 42m

Distance (Round-Trip): 6 miles

Difficulty: Easy to Moderate

Restrooms: Vault toilets are available at North Gate parking lot and Oxbow Picnic Area. Otherwise, follow best practices for remote waste management.

Parking: Parking is available at the Haskell Gate trailhead parking.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.

properties.name: Rocky Pond Road Trailhead - Katahdin Loop Road - Mile 5.75
properties.notes: Rocky Pond Road Trailhead - Katahdin Loop Road - Mile 5.75 https://www.nps.gov/places/rocky-pond-road-trailhead-katahdin-loop-road-mile-5-75.htm The Rocky Pond Road Trail is a 4.1 mile stretch of dirt logging road that allows cycling, hiking, and even horseback riding. Use road with caution. This road is used by authorized vehicles only.

properties.name: Rocky Pond Road Trailhead - Katahdin Loop Road - Mile 9
properties.notes:
Rocky Pond Road Trailhead - Katahdin Loop Road - Mile 9
https://www.nps.gov/places/rocky-pond-road-trailhead-katahdin-loop-road-mile-9.htm

The 4.1 mile Rocky Pond Road Trail allows bicycles, horses, and hikers. This road is used by authorized vehicles only. Use Rocky Pond Road with caution.

properties.name: Sandbank Gate
properties.notes:
Sandbank Gate
https://www.nps.gov/places/sandbank-gate.htm

Sandbank Stream Gate may be closed in spring and fall to prohibit vehicle travel when conditions are muddy. Travel during this time can cause damage to the road and vehicles.

properties.name: Seboeis Riverside Trail North Trailhead
properties.notes:
Seboeis Riverside Trail North Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/seboeis-riverside-trail-north.htm The northern access point for the Seboeis Riverside Trail is the start of a 6.75 mile one-way trail that leads south along the Seboeis River into the Seboeis Parcel of Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument.

Across Grand Lake Road is a recreation area where you can access a vault toilet and launch canoes and kayaks to paddle down the Seboeis.

properties.name: Seboeis Riverside Trail South Trailhead
properties.notes:
Seboeis Riverside Trail South Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/seboeis-riverside-trail-south.htm The southern access point for the Seboeis Riverside Trail is located in the Seboeis Parcel of Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument. This trailhead offers a 7.2 mile (one-way) out and back trail along the Seboeis River. The trail extends past the monument boundaries. To get to this location, a high clearance vehicle is recommended. There is an unmarked dirt parking area located just north of the trailhead (46.07529,-68.63553).

Note: Philpott Bridge and areas west of the Seboeis River are not within the boundaries of Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument.

The northern end of the trail is located off Grand Lake Road, 5.7 miles north of Shin Pond. In the winter, you can snowshoe from the north trailhead. This trailhead is not maintained during the winter.

properties.name: Seboeis Road Gate
properties.notes: Seboeis Road Gate https://www.nps.gov/places/seboeis-road-gate.htm The Seboeis Road Gate may be closed in spring and fall to prohibit vehicle travel when conditions are muddy. Travel during this time can cause damage to the road and vehicles. Check current conditions for most up to date information.

properties.name: Slash Trailhead
properties.notes:
Slash Trailhead https://www.nps.gov/places/slash-trailhead.htm Slash Trail starts nearby the Katahdin Overlook just off Katahdin Loop Road and connects approximately at the midpoint of Rocky Pond Road Trail. Expect tall grasses and thick vegetation along the trail.
 

Elevation Gain: 201ft / 61.3m

Distance(Round-Trip): 1.2 miles/ 1.9km

Difficulty: Easy

Restrooms: The closest vault toilet is at the Katahdin Loop Road Overlook.

Parking: Park completely off the gravel road. Do not block the road or trailhead.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.

properties.name: Stair Falls
properties.notes:
Stair Falls https://www.nps.gov/places/stair-falls.htm The East Branch of the Penobscot River flows over a series of parallel bedrock ridges that cause the river to appear to be flowing over stairs as it drops 18 feet within 8/10 of a mile. The name came from Maynard Marsh through a survey commissioned by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts in 1793. In his field notes Marsh wrote, "...at the foot of the handsomest falls I ever saw... as regular as a stair case." Stair Falls was recognized as a significant rapid in the state of Maine's evaluations of critical areas in the late 1970s and early 1980s. Access to the falls is along the International Appalachian Trail, with the fastest route beginning at Haskell Gate. Please be mindful that there is a campsite in this area.
 

Elevation Gain: 87ft / 26m

Distance (Round-Trip): 4 miles

Difficulty: Easy

Restrooms: The closest vault toilets are located at the North Gate parking lot and the Oxbow Picnic Area.

Parking: Parking is available at the Haskell Gate trailhead on New River Road.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife. Be mindful of the campsite area when visiting the falls.

properties.name: Swift Brook Road Gate
properties.notes:
Swift Brook Road Gate
https://www.nps.gov/places/swift-brook-road-gate.htm

The Swift Brook Road Gate may be closed in spring and fall to prohibit vehicle travel when conditions are muddy. This gate is not managed by NPS. Travel during this time can cause damage to the road and vehicles.

properties.name: The Hulling Machine
properties.notes: The Hulling Machine https://www.nps.gov/places/the-hulling-machine.htm The Hulling Machine is a beautiful waterfall that can only be seen and heard by paddling down the East Branch of the Penobscot River. You must portage around The Hulling Machine. This natural feature was named for what it did to logs as they passed through the rapids and ledge drops. Logs were once floated downstream by loggers to transport them by river during the log driving days.

properties.name: Twin Ponds
properties.notes:
Twin Ponds https://www.nps.gov/places/twin-ponds.htm Twin Ponds is a wetland area located just off the American Thread Road. Take a short hike to the viewpoint where there may be a chance to observe waterfowl and other wildlife.

Elevation Gain: none

Distance (Round-Trip): 0.5 miles

Difficulty: Easy

Restrooms: There are no restrooms available in this section of the monument.

Parking: Parking is available at the trailhead located on the American Thread Road.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.

properties.name: Valley Viewpoint
properties.notes:
Valley Viewpoint https://www.nps.gov/places/valley-viewpoint.htm Valley Viewpoint offers a vista that focuses on the landscape of Katahdin Woods and Waters National Monument and surrounding areas. To enjoy this scenic view, hike or bike 8 miles (one way) from Haskell Gate. This trail is considered strenuous with 1,369ft of elevation gain. Keep in mind, this is a 16 mile hike round trip. Due to its remote location, it is one of the least visited views in the monument. Hike or Bike to Valley View from Haskell Gate along the International Appalachian Trail.

Be prepared by bringing a map, food, and plenty of water. Check current conditions and local weather before visiting.

If you plan to visit this location in the winter, you will start your adventure by skiing or snowshoeing from the North Gate parking lot. Starting at North Gate parking lot increases the mileage to 22 miles (round-trip). Know your limits before your visit and review information on winter safety. Remember to pack your own snowshoes and/or skis!
 

Elevation Gain: 1,369ft / 417m

Distance(Round-Trip): 16 miles

Difficulty: Difficult

Restrooms: Vault toilets are available at the North Gate parking lot and Oxbow Picnic Area.

Parking: Parking is available at the Haskell Gate trailhead parking area.

Trail Etiquette: Leashed pets are allowed on this trail. Carry out all trash and food waste (fruit peels, shells, etc.). Do not feed the wildlife.

properties.name: Wassataquoik Gate Parking Lot
properties.notes:
Wassataquoik Gate Parking Lot https://www.nps.gov/places/wassataquoik-gate-parking.htm Wassataquoik Gate Parking Lot is the trailhead for destinations like Orin Falls (2.9 miles one-way), Deasey Mountain (5 miles one-way), and several campsites reachable by foot. The hike to Deasey Mountain requires a crossing of Wassataquoik Stream. Barnard Mountain (4.1 miles one-way) can also be reached from this parking lot. 

Accessibility:
The surface of the parking area is made of dirt, gravel, and rocks. It is leveled, but the surface can be uneven and muddy depending on the season. The vault toilet meets ADA standards.

Hours:
Open 24/7 when the Katahdin Loop Road is opened to traffic.

Getting Here:
Take Swift Brook Road past the welcome sign at the Loop Road Gate. Continue for approximately 1.9 miles to meet a junction. Turn right on the Loop Road towards Wassataquoik Stream Road. Continue for approximately 1.3 miles and turn right onto Wassataquoik Stream Road. Once on Wassataquoik Stream Road, travel for approximately 2.5 miles to reach the parking lot.

properties.name: Wassataquoik Stream Ford
properties.notes:
Wassataquoik Stream Ford https://www.nps.gov/places/wassataquoik-stream-ford.htm The Wassataquoik Ford is the designated crossing point for the IAT across Wassataquoik Stream. Look for the signs marked "FORD" on either side of the river for the crossing points. Proceed with caution. Wassataquoik Stream is prone to flash floods. Review information about stream crossing safety. Do not cross if water levels are high or if you do not feel comfortable with the conditions. 

Always be willing to turn back or wait for a more suitable time if a crossing appears too dangerous! Remember, no river crossing is worth your life.

properties.name: Wassataquoik Stream Road Gate
properties.notes:
Wassataquoik Stream Road Gate
https://www.nps.gov/places/wassataquoik-road-gate.htm

The Wassataquoik Stream Road Gate is usually open, but may be closed in the spring and fall to prohibit vehicle travel when conditions are muddy. Travel during this time can cause damage to the road and vehicles.
